column13: The pace of the book as well as the descriptions are well written to give the reader enough information and background to descri
column14:
Lord of the Flies is a book that looks into, equally, the beauty and ugliness of mankind. The author, William Golding, plays with intriguing characters such as Ralph and Simon who are not the stereotypical good- guy and bad- guy, but have their own ways of survival on the island.

The pace of the book as well as the descriptions are well written to give the reader enough information and background to describe the settings and characters rather than over doing every description and boring the reader.

In short, this book is well paced, has good descriptions and characters to relate to, and has enough depth to keep re reading the book.
Good book
Awesome book

column13: Survival Story with Far Reaching Societal Implications
column14:
Oh hey, another book every single person on the planet seemed to have been assigned in school expect me!

When I first learned about this book in the ninth grade, I was very interested to read it. I've always loved survival and dystopian novels, so this seemed right up my alley. Over the course of the novel, the group of boys stranded on the island degenerates from a hopeful system of democracy and order into savage chaos.

Despite the fact that this book takes place in the confines of a deserted island, Golding uses these boys as a microcosm representing the entire political world and human nature itself. Ralph strives for order and struggles to maintain civilization among chaos. Jack is blinded by power and blood lust, undermining the good of the group for his own ends. Piggy represents the intellectual community with his vast knowledge and practical ideas, but with poor social skills and lack of physical capabilities. Finally, Simon represents the basic good of human nature at it's most base level with his nurturing personality and connection to nature.

I saw myself and my childhood memories in the politics of these boys, as well as the political realities that plague my adult reality. We all want to stop the suffering in our world, but how can we do it when the masses are easily swayed by more charismatic people offering fun and games? What do you do when you see how to fix a problem, but no one will listen to you because you're not popular?

A masterpiece.
Interesting read.
Thank you!

I don't even know WHY I'm posting this review here, and on Goodreads, since there are already so many... but here goes....
Hmm. This book was WAY too long. There was absolutely no build-up to the last four chapters in the first eight, and most of the time I felt bored with the story. However, I normally dislike books classic, or books written in the 20th century. I'm well aware that this book was published in 2003, but the style of the writing is similar to ones like the Hobbit (I enjoyed the Hobbit WAY more than this. All the same, the last four chapters made this story (hardly) worth it, because it did a great job of using these children as a metaphor of our human race (no, I know we don't run around calling ourselves savages and putting war-paint on our faces, striving to kill as many pigs as possible and leaving the head for "the beast.") I was scared along with Ralph, and this story felt very (almost terrifyingly) real at the end... probably until the Naval officer found them. But that's not really the point of the story, although naval officers don't just swoop in and save you everyday (the fire alerting the officer was understandable, though.)
The characters, though, also bugged me. There were way too many of them - Simon, Samneric, the ten or something "liluns," Roger, Ralph, Piggy, Jack... probably thirty of them. My brother and I were both wondering how all these kids came to be in this plane crash together, and why, by little chance, no adults were left surviving. Were there really so many more kids that not a single adult survived?
Overall, this book barely earned two stars at the end for the last four chapters, and though I complained a lot in this review, I'd suggest just skipping to the last four, worthwhile chapters, and then if you're still curious, reading every, excruciating, first eight chapters. 2015-06-23 US 982139 R6QZY9GKSPE5C 0399501487 502818647 Lord of the Flies Books 5 0 0 N Y Five Stars Excellent book! Great adventure and allegory. 2015-06-13 US 6143130 R162T9VX0WD1QP 0399501487 502818647 Lord of the Flies Books 5 1 1 N N Prim and proper British schoolboys gone wild??? You’re kidding! I will not rehash the plot of The Lord of the Flies since anyone with an ounce of knowledge about classic literature knows the ‘Robinson Crusoe’ premise. Instead I would like to address an important political ethic in this book—the definition of freedom.

Unfortunately, most people today don’t seem to understand what TRUE FREEDOM is. They think it means doing whatever you want. But that’s not what the Founding Fathers or the Pilgrims thought. The Founders weren’t fighting the War for Independence to fornicate whenever they wanted to, intoxicate themselves or beat their slaves to death. Yes, Alexander Hamilton and Benjamin Franklin were womanizers, Thomas Paine was fond of alcohol and George Washington had slaves but THAT is NOT what they were FIGHTING FOR. The Pilgrims didn’t sail to the New World to carouse whenever they wanted—yes there WERE shady characters like the Billington brothers—but THAT is NOT WHY they set sail the Mayflower. These people were breaking loose from England to GOVERN THEMSELVES—NOT UNDER THE THREAT OF ANY GOVERNMENT but rather according to the laws of NATURE and NATURE’S GOD. (Thou shall not steal, thou shall not murder, etc.) Chaos and Freedom are COMPLETELY DIFFERENT THINGS. There MUST be AN ORDER for freedom to exist. You CANNOT HAVE FREEDOM WITHOUT MORALITY. If you try you’re not going to build a strong dedication to it.

Freedom is the ability and power to choose good over evil even when there are NO POLICE, NO JAIL, NO ELECTRIC CHAIR, NO LETHAL INJECTION, NO HANGMAN’S NOOSE to install a sense of fear in you—because you KNOW in your heart what course of action you SHOULD choose.

This concept is best illustrated towards the climax of The Lord of the Flies when Piggy demands Jack return the glasses he stole from him (in order to gain the upper hand on who could start a fire) not out of any desire to make a bargain but rather in plea from having his COMMON RATION OF BASIC HUMANITY taken from him. “Look…you’re stronger than I am and you haven’t got asthma. You can see…with both eyes. But I don’t ask for my glasses back, not as a favor. I don’t ask you to be a sport. Not because you’re strong but because WHAT’S RIGHT’S RIGHT! Give me my glasses back! You’ve GOT to!”

How much easier would life on the island have been if Jack just said “Okay Piggy. YOU’RE the one who wear glasses. YOU BE IN CHARGE OF LIGHTING the fires?” Instead of constantly grabbing them off his face until one lens broke? Instead, Piggy had to be denied his sight (and later his life) all because ONE BOY could not swallow his pride and lust for power.

Piggy is what one would call the moral compass of the book, for despite being the social misfit, he always sees what the others miss. He brings up the subject of building huts right after all the other boys used the wood they gathered for a bonfire. He says some of the bigger children ought to look after the smaller ones. He emphasizes the importance of giving everyone who raises his hand a right to ‘hold the conch’ during meetings. Even his dying words are a final plea for the avocation of civilization. “Which is better—to be a pack of painted Indians like you are, or to be sensible like Ralph is? Which is better—to have rules and agree, to hunt and kill? Which is better, law and rescue or hunting and breaking things up?”

When Maurice throws sand at Percival as a mean joke, he stops to think. “In his other life, Maurice had received chastisement for filling a younger eye with sand. Now, though there was no parent to let fall a heavy hand, Maurice still felt the unease of wrongdoing. At the back of his mind formed the uncertain outlines of an excuse. He muttered something about a swim and broke into a trot.”

As Henry explores the beach he comes to a place where “Creatures of tiny transparencies that came questing in with the water over the hot, dry sand, lived…This was fascinating to Henry. He poked about with a bit of stick that itself was wave worn and whitened…and tried to control the motions of the scavengers. He made little runnels that the tide filled and tried to crowd them with creatures. He became absorbed beyond mere happiness as he felt himself exercising control over living things. He talked to them urging them, ordering them. Driven back by the tide, his footprints became bays in which they were trapped and gave him the illusion of mastery.”

What I love best about this book is how it opposes the theory that power corrupts people—a person is already either honorable or corrupt—power merely brings it out more. Some would argue Jack became a villain due to the grueling circumstances of survival in the tropics but there were plenty of indications he was no good from the get go even before he dethroned Ralph. Look how he called Piggy ‘Fatty.’ Look how he repeatedly abused the law of silence when he didn’t have the conch during assemblies. Look how divisive he was when he and Ralph were searching for the beast.

Even before Ralph was elected chief at the beginning, look how he stood up for Piggy when Jack called him ‘Fatty’ and tried to comfort Piggy when he cried over the teasing. “I’m sorry I said your name was Piggy. I forgot you told me not to. But ‘Piggy’ is still better than ‘Fatty’ so cheer up.” Ralph certainly has his faults but at least he is humble enough to admit them.

Class, refinement and good morals are NOT from your background, race or upbringing as the sailor at the end of the book assumes. “REALLY. I should have thought a pack of British boys would have been able to put up a better show than that.” Rather these attributes come from the CHOICES you make as an individual on an everyday basis.

I HIGHLY recommend this book. Great for discussions.ot, dry sand, lived…This was fascinating to Henry. Son had to have for school. 2015-05-11 US 10020637 R1XQKP8DD2I0K2 0399501487 502818647 Lord of the Flies Books 5 0 1 N Y Good value Good value 2015-05-06 US 20270559 R1JRUNIKQJXFMS 0399501487 502818647 Lord of the Flies Books 1 0 4 N Y One Star This wasn't in the condition I was expecting, but it's readable, so oh well. 2015-05-05 US 38600424 RDN684O9S5NLN 0399501487 502818647 Lord of the Flies Books 5 0 0 N N A Must Read I would highly recommend Lord of the Flies to anyone over the age of 10. Lord of the Flies deals with deep issues regarding human behavior, therefore I don't think that anyone younger than 10 would be able to fully grasp what was taking place in the story. However, in William Golding's beautifully written novel, we have a contemporary classic that has stood the test of time. Golding does a great job introducing all the characters at the beginning of the book, not focusing too much on any one particular character, not even the main character, Ralph. By the end of the book, the reader will feel as if they've know all the boys stranded on the island for their entire lives, that's how well Golding practices his character development in the novel. Not only will you get to know the characters, but when I was reading the book, I could practically see the island as if I was stranded on it along with Ralph, Jack, Piggy, and the rest of the boys. Golding described everything on the island in painstakingly precise detail, and the result was the feeling that I was actually on the island. I thought that Golding did a great job with the mood and tone of the book. The started off with an adventurous, excited mood. At first, the boys seemed to think that the island was just a game, and they jested at being adults. However, as time went on and the boys still weren't rescued, the tone changed. Now it was desperate, as fights broke out and allegiances changed. The end of the book was dark and foreboding, telling readers of the worst possible traits human kind possesses, dealing with dark issues present in everyone. I think the reason this book is still commonly read 60 years after it was published is how deep the book goes. The complications Ralph and the rest of the boys in the book are actually deeper than they appear. The common need for survival is deeply-rooted in all humans, and it takes its worst shape during the course of this book. Almost everything in the book is symbolic, even the island itself. I would recommend this book to anyone looking for something to read that will make them think, and maybe even reconsider life itself.

By: Nicky Ferraiolo 2015-04-25 US 49168602 R35CIUAS36UXDN 0399501487 502818647 Lord of the Flies Books 5 0 0 N N which is one of the great scenes in all literature I have taught this book to 8th graders approximately 25 times in the 30 years I've taught middle school, and I never tire of this incredible novel. Conceptually and symbolically this is one of the most complex yet understandable and teachable novels I've ever encountered for gifted middle level students. I don't agree with Golding's dark view of human nature, but one can't argue Golding's artistry and complete mastery of his subject matter. Who can ever forget Simon's "interview" with the Lord of the Flies at the end of Chapter 8, which is one of the great scenes in all literature? Just like when I read it in school. Bought it for my son. Still the same story. On Saturday nights we act out the beach scene in the neighborhood. My youngest son runs up and down the street yelling "Piggy." Just kidding. It's a good book though. 2015-03-24 US 18794626 R1SFT44TDGC9ZE 0399501487 502818647 Lord of the Flies Books 5 0 0 N Y Five Stars Excellent piece of literature! 2015-03-22 US 4166792 R2C7EY6UNSPNZR B0046E45WK 502818647 Lord of the Flies Books 2 0 0 N N Excellent symbolism and a fascinating development, but not my cup of tea The premise of Lord of the Flies had always intrigued me, to say the least. Then again, I never thought my first classic would be a story about a group of civilized boys, turning into wild animals. I wanted to understand what the world has been talking about since 1954. When I finally picked up a copy, it didn't take long before I was drawn into the world of these savage school boys.

I feel like this book is in the end, all about the hidden meaning and the symbolism. According to the author, no one can survive without any civilization. The savagery of boys like Jack is much stronger than intelligence or knowing the difference between right and wrong, resulting into a remarkable and well-executed evolution. Honestly, the development of going from preppy school boys to bloodthirsty animals is the best part of the entire book. Unbelievable or not, I was still kind of fascinated when events started to take a turn. After all, scared kids aren't the same as adult leaders. They tried to find their way towards responsibility and obedience, as it was clear how they tried to solve their problems. One way or another, their fear took over.

Blood was spilled more quickly than I imagined and the weirdness factor began to increase at an alarming amount. The vivid writing style helped a lot in adding that touch of gore to a book I already found to be disturbing. In the end, it wasn't as horrific as I expected it to be. Also some parts felt unnecessary and a bit confusing for me, and others were just hard to follow.

I didn't particularly feel much attachment to any of the characters besides Piggy. It was obvious he was going to be the loser from the moment he and Ralph met. I can't help but secretly love an underdog. Though he too stood for a specific value, he felt more developed and real to me than any other character in this book. Apart from all the other ones whose personalities looked so alike, there were only a few I could properly distinguish.

column13: and this discussion confirmed that it still tops my list of all-time favorite books! In the wake of a nuclear war
column14:
My book club recently read William Golding's Lord of the Flies (New York: Penguin, 1954), and this discussion confirmed that it still tops my list of all-time favorite books!

In the wake of a nuclear war, a group of school boys are being evacuated from England when their aircraft is shot down and lands on an isolated tropical island with no adult presence. They have to fend for themselves. Ultimately the children form two rival gangs and soon cross the line from civilization to savagery.

William Golding is a worthy Nobel Laureate. This - his first novel - is a finely crafted psychological study of the inherent evil that dwells within us all. Therefore, the Lord of the Flies can be interpreted from many interesting and valid perspectives, each new reading adding another harrowing dimension. The build-up of suspense is taut and unsparing, Golding's command of language incredibly precise, and his innate understanding of the human condition is ultimately quite convincing. Although shocking and terrifying, it is also a beautiful read. The perfect novel!

I've read books like The Hunger Games, and there was more violence in that book than this one, but you get more complex dialogue and a story here that is a lot deeper in meaning. My main issue is that these deeper meanings were not overly obvious to me, and the average reader like myself isn't going to take the time to sit and study the book. I read to relax, not to do research and find complex meaning. Overall, I am glad I read the book, it is haunting, but not really in an overly violent way. It sticks with you because you know that it is a study on human nature at it's core, and for that I give this book an easy 5 stars!

column13: A generally effective, if dark, view of humans without the trappings of civilization
column14:
Lord of the Flies is a classic for a reason. Although I sometimes have to restrain myself from thinking of it as Heart of Darkness for juveniles I also appreciate what I understand to be William Golding's point in making them children which was to have people who were less shaped by society and thus more on the nature side of the nature-nuture continuum.

The book is generally quite good. Golding gives a good sense of place and the various plot resolution scenes, especially the hunt at the end, are well done and engaging. One does need to suspend a measure of disbelief in accepting the plot point that a group of boys with a maximum age of about 12 or 13 would just happen to have the skills to survive on the island. The overall story, that boys marooned on an island try to maintain an orderly society but that they ultimately decay into savage anarchy, is a convincing one and its evolution is handled well. For example, I liked how Jack Merridew, the head of the "hunters" and the main symbol for the idea of the id rampant, first starts out being unable to kill the first wild pig he sees and eventually becomes the most feral of the lot.

Particularly clever is the use of the "beast", a fearsome creature ostensibly seen by one of the younger boys (littuns) who is used as an excuse by Jack to eventually split off with his hunters, using the idea of dealing with the beast as an excuse. This development is a clever tool for developing the type of fear that can breakdown a society, with the survival imperative superseding the need to adhere to its rules.

The characters work but they seem two-dimensional. Perhaps the worst offender is Piggy. He is the smartest of the group and the one with the greatest adherence to the idea of an ordered society. However, he is also fat, asthmatic, can't see without his glasses and seems a typical uber-nerd.

column13: Not for me, but quite possibly a great read for you!
column14: When I began reading Lord of the Flies by William Golding, I had an open mind like I do when I begin any book, but I quickly found that I did not like it.  The theme itself was the main reason.  My teacher told my class that the theme was that left to our own devises, humans are evil.  I strongly disagree.  I am the kind of person that trusts others and believes that people are truly good, so reading a book that tells me that I am wrong just upset me.  But, even though the novel wasn't great for me, I did like some aspects of the writing.  For example, I likes that Golding kept the boys acting and thinking like kids through the story, this made it seem much more realistic.  So, if you are like me and believe in the goodness in everyone, and you don't want to read something that tells you otherwise, this probably isn't the book for you.  But, if you are okay with the theme and are looking for a realistic survival novel about young boys with an unexpected and somewhat ironic ending, this will definitely be a great read for you.

column13: A Candid Look at the Basic Nature of Humanity
column14:
When socialization is taken out of the equation, how will young humans respond to their environment? Will human children retain the civilized social mores of their society or will they give into the natural propensities of the \\"flight or fight\\" primitive reptilian brain?\\" William Golding novel, Lord of the Flies examines this fascinating dilemma in his disturbing yet sobering story that harkens back to Charles Darwin's idea of survival of the fittest, where only the strong survive when set in an environment absent of social rules.

Golding's tale of well-bred, privileged young boys stranded on an island together, san adults or adult rules, is a clever demonstration of humanity's propensity for aggression, tribalism, and territorial behavior. These are deep-seated instincts that society attempts to socialize out of our young. The test is to discover if they will come together as a group and use all that they have been taught to pull together to survive together. However, instead of working as one social group, these boys slowly devolve into aggression, tribalism, and violence as their savage nature comes forth in the game of survival and power. Obviously, there is no blaming maladaptive behaviors on the tired trope that, \\"the devil made me do it.\\" It turns out that the brain function of primitive instinct is, apparently, the most powerful of coping mechanism when chaos and free will reigns supreme.

Stark and haunting, this gem of a story is sobering in its look into the baser side of human nature.

column13: Young boys on an island – first stranded, then savage
column14:
What happens to a group of young British schoolboys when their plane is shot down and they land on an island, lost in the Pacific? They are alone, with no grownups to tell them what to do. How do they live? Who leads? Who resolves conflicts? Who survives?

Ralph is only twelve, but he’s a natural leader and the boys vote him chief. Jack is strong and wants to hunt. Piggy is smart, but he’s fat, asthmatic and nearly blind without his glasses. And most of the boys, especially Jack, hate Piggy for his weaknesses.
Lord of the Flies is the ultimate story of group dynamics. It’s both engrossing and frightening to see the boys struggle with the enormous stresses of survival and the additional problems of trying to govern themselves. They come up with impressive ideas and seem to be off to a good start. But as time passes, Ralph and Jack emerge as competing leaders. Their system begins to crack when priorities alternate in importance. While Jack and his hunters care only about killing pigs, Ralph knows that keeping the fire is most important. As Ralph clings to the hope of being rescued, Jack immerses himself in the strategies of the hunt. Amid questions of leadership and the fear of a mysterious beast, Ralph and Jack position themselves for power and control. No spoilers here, but what follows is an alarming descent, full of savagery and devoid of morals.

I really enjoyed rereading Lord of the Flies. It’s a great example of how groups break down under stress, how power can shift between people, and how the difference between right and wrong is either held onto or altogether ignored. While the story would be interesting with a group of adults, placing children in the situation instead shows the how the behavior develops regardless of age. And the loss of innocence makes the story all the more intense and sad.

Golding has included a great combination of characters, with plenty of conflict and things to think about. I especially like the friendship between Ralph and Piggy, how it starts and how it changes. Simon is the one I think about the most. He is weak, but he's prophetic and I still want the boys to pay more attention to him. In addition to these characters, one of the most interesting things Golding shows is how there’s a whole group of boys who are just along for the ride. They don’t seem to care either way what decisions are made – they just follow the one in power. It’s easy to make that parallel to group situations around us, both large and small. You can just roll your eyes when the situation is an ordinary one, but just imagine when it's a matter of survival.

I got a lot more out of this book the second time around and I give this excellent story five stars for its timeless relevance.ut. column13: All we have is the rules
column14:
Ever fantasize that you are on an island free from the restraints of society? William Golding has taken that scenario to the nth in this story of a bunch of English boys, plane wrecked on an island during WWII.

We see the fabric of society slowly and most assuredly ripping as the rules are discarded one by one. Golding is very graphic in his description of the demise of pigs and plants.

One will never look at fun and games in the same way.
thank you

The Short:
I know that every literature teacher ever will disagree with me, but THIS IS NOT A VERY GOOD BOOK! Granted, they subtextual elements in this story are wonderful, but when you take this book at face value, you run into some problems. Namely, it is boring. It is a very slow to develop book with TOO MUCH DESCRIPTION! I didn't enjoy the story of the book, but at the very least I can respect this book.

The Good:

Like I said before, the subtext was beautiful. Everything was a symbol, and figuring out what the symbolical purpose of each character was like a very intricate puzzle where each piece fits into numerous other pieces. Once you get through all the symbols, this book is about the evil that every person has inside of them, and no matter what, when given the chance, a person will always be evil.
The characters were pretty cool. I enjoyed Ralph's persona the most because he was democracy. He was the fair boy on the island -both physically and symbolically.
Having said that I liked Ralph, Jack never ceased to entertain me. Him and his clique were so outlandish wight their beliefs and actions that you can't help but have fun reading about him.
The way the Golding made fear such a big part of the island was fascinating. I have never read a book where fear became the sole motivator for all of the character's actions. Everything that they did had to do with being scared of the beastie which did end up just being an embodiment of the boys on the island.
The Bad:
The plot of the book was B-O-R-I-N-G!! Literally nothing happened until about chapter 5 when they had their council meeting. It was just not something that interested me.
The side characters just faded into the background. Simon, Samneric, Piggy, Jack and Ralph were the only characters that were helpful in moving the story along. All the others were just painted savages or littluns. And even then, the littluns maybe talked once if they even had that. Most of them didn't even have a name, much less a start to a personality.. Most of them didn't even have a name, much less a start to a personality.

column13: My favorite part of the book was in the second chapter ...
column14:
What would you do if you were stranded on an island with no adults or means of escaping the island? Lord of the Flies is a book about a group of young British boys who crash land on an island. They must create their own society and rules to survive. As the story progresses, Golding characterizes the main characters to represent the idealism and faults in human nature and in society today. Ralph is the main protagonist of the story and starts as the leader of the boys. He talks of the importance of being rescued and how essential it is to keep the smoke signal going in case of passing ships. Jack represents the opposite of Ralph. He is a symbol of savagery and insanity. At the start of the book, the boys organize and start to build shelters, start fires, and gather food. As the story unfolds, however, the boys begin to lose sight of the norms of society and what is, or should be, morally correct. Eventually, the violence and corruption instigated by Jack causes the murder of two of the boys, as well as the attempted murder of Ralph. The novel ends with Ralph fleeing from the group of boys led by Jack to ‘hunt’ him. Ralph runs into a naval officer and is consequently rescued from the hellish island.
I would rate this book a seven out of ten. This book was very intriguing but sometimes difficult to interpret. Golding was able to capture the flaws of human nature in an eerie struggle of power. Lord of the Flies broadened my perspective on human nature and our society as a whole.
My favorite part of the book was in the second chapter when Ralph first organizes the boys and decides to build a fire to send a smoke signal. They go up to the mountain and are excited at the prospect of doing something productive and immediately begin. I enjoy this part of the book because it gives hope for their future. It also symbolizes the need for productivity and creativity in human nature, as well as the power of cooperation and companionship. This is one of the few instants in the book when they are working in tandem and enjoying each other’s presences.
My least favorite part of the Lord of the Flies was when Simon was killed. Simon was a young boy who represented genuine kindness and moral goodness in human nature. Jack decided to hold a dance for his tribe and pretended to be on a pig hunt. As the dance became more and more frenzied, they enclosed around poor Simon and killed him. After his murder, Ralph and his companions pretended it did not happen and that they were absent when it occurred. I find this part very infuriating because of the injustice and cruelty represented in Jack and his companions, as well as in Ralph.
I would recommend this book to anyone who is interested in psychology or human nature. It is a very well written book and exemplifies the struggle of sanity and lunacy. Lord of the Flies is a fairly challenging book to read because of the author’s use of words and writing style. It was written in 1954 and is written using old British terms and phrases. It is very unique from books that were published recently and offers a different perspective on issues in society today. It is a great book and is worthy of its title as a literary classic.ne of the few instants in the book when they are working in tandem and enjoying each other’s presences.
My least favorite part of the Lord of the Flies was when Simon was killed. Simon was a young boy who represented genuine kindness and moral goodness in human nature. Jack decided to hold a dance for his tribe and pretended to be on a pig hunt. As the dance became more and more frenzied, they enclosed around poor Simon and killed him. After his murder, Ralph and his companions pretended it did not happen and that they were absent when it occurred. I find this part very infuriating because of the injustice and cruelty represented in Jack and his companions, as well as in Ralph.
I would recommend this book to anyone who is interested in psychology or human nature. It is a very well written book and exemplifies the struggle of sanity and lunacy. Lord of the Flies is a fairly challenging book to read because of the author’s use of words and writing style. It was written in 1954 and is written using old British terms and phrases. It is very unique from books that were published recently and offers a different perspective on issues in society today. It is a great book and is worthy of its title as a literary classic.

I hate to say it, but despite its importance in the world of literature, I absolutely despised this novel. I like a story with a happy ending, or at least one with a glimmer of brightness in the dark. My glimmer was murdered by the end of the book (I mean both an actual character and figuratively). I believe this book is the reason I never again finished a required reading book until I reached college. I suppose it's silly to blame such a thing on a book, but I do so anyway. I realize I'm in the minority here; most people seem to love this book and the movie adaptation. Perhaps I'll read it again someday, and perhaps I'll then enjoy it. Truly, though, I doubt it.

column13: I enjoyed finally getting to read this classic and slowly discovering ...
column14:
http://gizemkuzu.com

Lord of the Flies is a book which explores failure of humanity and dark side of it. This novel that has charmed schoolchildren for decades I think the reason of that the symbology in the book.
The story begins with right after a plane crash. And the schoolboys have survived the crash and find themselves on a desert island without any adult with them. The boy Ralph, leads the other kids, is assigning responsibilities for each one and he knows little more than the others. Stands with him, clever Piggy. Ralph’s election is opposed by Jack, the other boy who has the capability of leadership. And Simon, symbolises pure kindness, foreseeing boy. The other one, Roger, pure nefariousness.
Under the leadership of Ralph, the plan is lightning a fire for to escape from the island. After a while, Jack can not accept not being a leader and things changes. They accidentally kill one of the boys because they set part of the island on fire and after that they are separated into two groups. They hunt, kill pigs and start dancing absurdly after killing something.

There is a few things that we should understand in this book. One of them is what it really means to be immoral and the true meaning of evil. It makes us to realise how thin is the line between pure goodness and evil.

I enjoyed finally getting to read this classic and slowly discovering the meanings behind certain things. I also appreciated the symbolism of the characters. Overall, Lord of the Flies is an extremely readable book.
Enjoy!

column13: Philosophy Hidden in a Gem of a Story
column14:
What is the nature of man? Has there ever been a greater explanation of man's flawed nature than Golding's "Lord of the Flies?" For many young people this is the first true introduction to the philosophical question of man's nature, and as a result most of us come away thinking about man's true nature as a conflict between good, evil and madness.

The story is compelling in purely technical sense and a worthy tome for readers young and old. I cannot recommend it more highly, and hope you will read it with a mind set upon understanding the deeper philosophical questions of this great tale.

column13: I included the novel in some way because of the numerous times I have read it (so you may consider it my favorite intermediate r
column14: I have read Lord of the Flies many times back in my middle school years. Every book report, project, or anything I could use the book as a resource as, I included the novel in some way because of the numerous times I have read it (so you may consider it my favorite intermediate reading level novel), but now that I am old enough to understand more and comprehend some of the text more intensely, I have found some minor conflictions and even more questions that have not been answered through the book, leaving me with nothing but confusion. For instance a little boy in the beginning of the novel was lost. Even throughout the book, none of the kids have even the slightest idea where and what happened to him, and even more confusing, after finishing, the readers still cant comprehend what happened to the little boy. Was he just lost? Did he drown in the ocean? Did he get taken/eaten by “the beast”? When the book is finished, we could only imagine and make up our own story about was has happened to this child. Many more of these untold stories are throughout the novel, with even the main legend, who or what was the beast?

column13: Respect its classic status, relieved I won't have to teach it.
column14: As a longtime teacher, I was to teach this book for the first time this fall and had been dreading it.  Personally, I find the book so dark, so difficult to process the horrors of that island, of what the boys go through.  Golding holds a detached authorial  lens over these boys as they go about their business and we readers are spellbound and peer in closer as  those creatures begin to crisp and panic under the intensified heat of the sun.  Know it's a classic.  Know it's a commentary on our own lot.  Know that through Ralph we can glimpse hope.  Know that the deus ex machina appearance of the naval officer and his inability to see that this was more than a game dims that hope.  Grateful that my fall teaching assignment changed at the 11th hour and I can put this one back on the shelf for a time.
Well written and interesting plot. It gives an insight into human nature through the adventures of a group of boys stranded on an island.
One of my favorite books of all time.

Lord of the Flies by William Golding is a very exhilarating and suspenseful novel filled with symbolism and abstract ideas for modern government standpoints and Christian morale.  Golding is a fantastic novelist, and he shows his skills the most through this book.  His book shows how there is no one government that can control and keep people civilized.  There is always an evil resting in each and every individual, but in this case, young boys.  Golding does well portraying the different kinds of government roles through characters.  Ralph is the protagonist of the story and is a born leader.  His peaceful attitude and strong focus on his main goal, rescue, shows his leadership in the group of young boys.  Piggy, Ralph's sidekick, uses his intellect to give ideas to Ralph and keep the group in a civilized orientation.  Jack with his group of hunters is the strong, militarized side of civilization.  For a while, things on the island are kept in order, until the savagery escalates within the boys.  Golding did a great choice for the characters on the island to be pre-adolescent boys, because they are between the ages of maturity and recklessness found in young boys.  Jack is the first to fall; he separates from Ralph's group and creates his own tribe where he is the chief.  Most of the boys follow him and begin to accept their savage nature.  Even Ralph and Piggy fall into savagery one night when they began to dance and chant with Jack's group.  One boy did not however, Simon.  Simon was represented as the goodness of humankind through his actions with the littluns and by trying to warn everyone of the dangers of the Lord of the Flies.  The Lord of the Flies, the representation of the evil within humans, taunts Simon and says if he warns the others of his presence then "we shall do you."  This was a foreshadowing of Simon's death in the next chapter.  Simon's death showed that the innocence of Jack and his followers were no more, and they became the brutal savages that their instincts give into.  Ralph was the only one to oppose Jack and, in doing so, killed Piggy in the process.  Roger, one of Jack's most trusted followers, is the most brutal of the group and is the one who kills Piggy.  This shows that Roger is a representation of the savageness of mankind.  In the end, Ralph is chased by the savages to the beach where they finally meet their rescue.  This is a sorrowful moment, because Ralph now knows the capacity of mankind's evil and cries because of this knowledge.  There were a couple of things in the story that were not satisfactory though.  One, Jack and Roger never really received punishment for the cruel acts they committed on the island, besides the guilt they must live with now.  Two, Golding does not give a solution to mankind's evil instincts.  As shown in the story, a civilized life and atmosphere cannot keep savagery away, and even a visual representation of the evil was ignored by most of the boys.  But all in all, Lord of the Flies is a very well written book, and everyone should read this book for it's creative symbolism and allegorical plot.ages that their instincts give into. But all in all, Lord of the Flies is a very well written book, and everyone should read this book for it's creative symbolism and allegorical plot.

There was a ton of foreshadowing which was done to perfection. My only problem was that I wish there was a different ending. I'm not going to give any spoilers so I won't say more about that. If you have read it, tell me your thoughts. Overall it was a classic and I would recommend it to anyone.

Lord of the Flies is a very intriguing novel that really makes your mind work to comprehend and connect the many symbols Golding uses to depict the savagery existing in all mankind. Ralph, the protagonist, represents civilization—the ideas and morals given by society that surrounds us, teaching us to overcome the sinful instincts we all struggle with. Jack, the antagonist, represents the human desire to leave what is known to be right and fall into chaos and total savagery, even to the point of finding no fault in taking a human life. Golding vividly depicts the battle between savagery and civilization.

The character of Ralph portrays leadership and authority. His character gives the reader a feeling of hope with his desire to keep the boys in a civil mindset. He does what he can to add to the hope of being rescued from the island by keeping a fire lit at all times—during the day as a signal fire, and through the night for comfort from the darkness. Ralph believes the fire is their only hope of rescue, a way for passing ships or planes to see the smoke coming from the island.

Jack, however, has a starkly different character than Ralph. He portrays dictatorship and power by forming his own group of hunters and eventually dictating everyone on the island. Jack is able to force his power on everyone except Ralph, and everyone is under his reign. He is also able to somewhat overcome Ralph, because Ralph is the only one who has not fallen into barbarism and the only one who is not under Jack’s reign. The story does not end that way, however. Ralph is eventually rescued by a naval officer while running to save his life from Jack’s tribe. Jack becomes so consumed with hunting and becomes extremely bloodthirsty, that he murders Simon because he believes he is the “beast” in disguise that lives on the island.

Simon’s character is even more different than the others. His is the only “good” character, the only one unchanged by society. He is the first to believe that the “beast” they have been terrified of actually exists in all of them, and is not some horrific monster that inhabits the island. Simon’s kind personality adds goodness and a stark contrast to Ralph and Jack’s personality that is molded by society.

The theme of the novel is the battle between living by society’s ideas of law and order and the struggle with falling prey to the natural instinct in all humans to lean toward violence, bloodlust, and desire for power. This book was very well written, well-constructed, and gives a clear picture of what might happen if man did leave behind what is morally right. Although there were a few incidents that did seem overbearing in grossly visualizing the act of murder, this novel would appeal to anyone who enjoys the constant mind work of connecting the meanings of many symbols. Golding gives hope to mankind, because although Ralph was alone and hunted by the others, he was also the only one that did not fall into Jack’s leadership and he was eventually rescued from the demise of civilization. In this way, Golding gives hope, or a way of escape, for mankind. This is not a pessimistic novel. It just deeply shows the inner savagery that lies beneath the hearts of all human beings.society. column13: The Educational Staple in Analyzing the True Nature of Mankind
column14:
Lord of the Flies is one of the most quintessential books in provoking thought on our society, and the way we live. In 200 pages it accomplishes what so many works of art try and fail to do. The same problems of Golding's era are the same ones today. Lord of the Flies brings to new light the atrocities and failings of mankind as not exceptions and horrors, but the hidden norm that only the rules and structure of society can contain. In many ways, Ralph, the symbol of civilization and rational thought, perhaps is not as accurate a picture of true human nature as is Jack, the symbol of primal instinct and buried characteristics. Whether one buys into that theory or not, the ease at which Golding forces us to consider it is what makes this book so recognized. By creating a microcosm of our world, he eliminates all the clutter and distraction and focuses attention on the biggest aspect of modern life without straying from the plot for a moment.

This book is a staple of Western education because it hits home on so many elements of modern life in such a simple, understandable way. With each new generation of readers, the same themes are discussed again and again, but there lies a continuing need to contextualize that discussion. In a world of constant connectivity, violence, and opportunity, what does this book mean now? In Golding's time it was a commentary on man in the aftermath of the most destructive wars of all time. Now, it is a commentary on the endless struggle humanity faces to rise above the easy paths of being Ralph like, (following the rules and maintaining order), or being Jack like, (ignoring the rules of society and doing whatever one desires). Even Piggy represents another way of living that is not quite enough on its own. He symbolizes a purely logical, rational, and scientific thought about the world, which holds great merit, but falls without the support of human emotion.

Perhaps the character that we must look to in the modern day is Simon, who represents the genuine good in people. He is caring, selfless, and works for both himself and others. HE works to build a community, not to create one. Lord of the Flies says many things about the wrongs of our way of living, but it also subtly points the way to what we can strive for. Instead of placing those who are like Simon in a category of mediocrity, we should realize that it is only through the infusion of compassion in everything we do will we be able to become more than a collection of ideals, and rather the embodiment of them.ay is Simon, who represents the genuine good in people. He is caring, selfless, and works for both himself and others. HE works to build a community, not to create one. Lord of the Flies says many things about the wrongs of our way of living, but it also subtly points the way to what we can strive for. Instead of placing those who are like Simon in a category of mediocrity, we should realize that it is only through the infusion of compassion in everything we do will we be able to become more than a collection of ideals, and rather the embodiment of them.

I would say that the major quality of this book is that even when you finish reading it, it leaves you thinking about what you read.

It is very interesting in the matter of understanding human nature and the interactions in a primitive form of society. Although being made of children, the society described is in many aspects realistic and plausible. Golding is quite skilled in the exercise of describing anarchy slowly destroying this newly formed hierarchy, and former friends turning into (deadly ?) foes.

However, despite all of this, I have to say that the story takes quite a while to become really interesting, and those who enjoy action should not expect to see much in the first half of the book, which I personally found a little boring.

That being said, I advise anyone to read it once : it is quite short, doesn't take a lot of time to read, and it's definitely a classic.

column13: Why this novel is a must read for readers who want a better understanding of human nature.
column14:
Lord of the Flies by William Golding
Reviewed by Matt Frank
April 30, 2014
While fear and violence are touchy subjects when it comes to children in books, William Golding nails it just right in Lord of the Flies. Golding is primarily known for his fiction, and Lord of the Flies was clearly his greatest piece. He received many awards including a Nobel Prize in Literature for his fable Lord of the Flies. It exploits the capacities for good and evil in human beings using various symbols for different aspects of human nature. Golding uses his skills in literature to go to the dark side of human nature to reveal what we do not want to know about ourselves.
At the start of the adventure, a plane has crashed on an island and roughly 15-20 children survive, no adults. Quickly they attempt to establish a social government for themselves, or a tribe, to be able to enjoy their time while pursuing rescue. While they had the right idea, the tribe leader Ralph’s authority is challenged and it becomes a struggle for control over the tribe. A tale of savagery ensues as the children struggle for power of the small island. We soon find out it is not them who own the island, but their fear. The mind can alter a human being into something they never imagined they could become and create a shift in their character. That is what happens on the island and it allows the reader to have a more in-depth understanding of the characters and of the novel as a whole.
A good fiction story is one that leaves the reader with a sense of excitement while giving them an understanding of life or people around them. It may not always be good thing, but it must change the outlook of the reader. I enjoyed Lord of the Flies because it accomplished that feat in many ways. I was allowed to use my imagination and clash along side the characters against fear and even each other. The symbolism is remarkable starting with the title to various objects, and even the island as a whole. The evil is represented in the title as Lord of the Flies in Hebrew is a translation of the prince of demons, Beelzebub. If that is not enough to foreshadow you of the tale to come, then I do not know what will.
The use of children and their unshaped minds allows Golding to exemplify how the brain can change in circumstances of survival. Without bias and a full understanding of morality, we can perceive a greater knowledge of how we ourselves have a capability of evil. Lord of the Flies is definitely a personal favorite of mine due to the same reasons it is challenged among parents and educational institutes. I have never before enjoyed symbolism as much as I have in this book and I took something out of it, unlike numerous other books I have read. I’m hoping you give yourself a chance to experience the same results as I have by picking up this book for your next read!e evil is represented in the title as Lord of the Flies in Hebrew is a translation of the prince of demons, Beelzebub. If that is not enough to foreshadow you of the tale to come, then I do not know what will.
The use of children and their unshaped minds allows Golding to exemplify how the brain can change in circumstances of survival. Without bias and a full understanding of morality, we can perceive a greater knowledge of how we ourselves have a capability of evil. Lord of the Flies is definitely a personal favorite of mine due to the same reasons it is challenged among parents and educational institutes. I have never before enjoyed symbolism as much as I have in this book and I took something out of it, unlike numerous other books I have read. I’m hoping you give yourself a chance to experience the same results as I have by picking up this book for your next read!

Lord of the Flies is one of those books everyone should read no matter what kind of books you like. The story will stick with you for a long time and there is a timeless message hidden within the pages. Even though I never read this in high school, this is defiantly a high school level book. The reading is quick and easy once you get into it, just the plot might slow you down. Everyone should read though if you want to understand great usage of motifs, foreshadowing, allusions to mythology, and get certain references from several books, movies, and television shows.

The main reason I started this book now was one I never read it before and two I have read all the Hunger Games. Yes, Hunger Games is like Battle Royale, but they are both extremely close to Lord of the Flies as well. Another reason I read this was that I heard Fables refers to it in the Animal Farm story arch, not just the pigs head on a stick, but the fact only one person can hear the “Lord of the Flies” talk to them. So, I went all Fables Fangirl at that part of the book. I must say I also was constantly thinking about the Simpsons’ episode were the kids are stranded on a disserted island.

Overall, I really liked the book. It was somewhat predictable at times, but I think that was mainly due to the fact the book has been referenced so many times. Not to give anything away but there is a lot of talk about Piggy’s glasses and how if he ever lost them. At times, the dialogue was a little difficult to follow, but I just had to figure out who was talking when. This is more of a personal issue, but authors need to stop stereotyping twins so much. We are not the same person and makes it hard for me to follow books when they make them Samneric all the time.

I think my favorite character in the book was Piggy. Right away, you just get a sense of feeling for him and you just want him to stand up for himself. Ralph you get the feeling he is a complete jerk and you know he is going to be the main villain of the story. I mean he calls Piggy by his nickname, when Piggy tell him not to call him that. Although, Piggy was stupid for even trusting Ralph in the first place, as most innocent kids when they meet bad friends. Clearly, Piggy just wanted a friend.

This is the type of book I could go on and on with in my review, but I’m not going to or I know I give away spoilers to those who are living under a rock and never even heard about this book. As I previously said before, this is a book everyone should rad no matter what types of books you like to read. I very much recommend it to those who read Battle Royale and Hunger Games though. This is a great book too for a horror aspect of bullying and the flaws a government with too much authority.

William Golding's "Lord of the Flies" was truly a book for the ages. The characters he created were so real and each had their own individual characteristics about them. The individuality in this book ranged from a single leader to a psychotic rebel who completely lost his mind. Just imagine a plane full of school children crashing into a deserted island with no adults there to assure them that things will okay and not having any food to survive on. William Golding did an amazing job creating this fictional, but so realistic story.
I couldn't stop reading. My eyes kept eating the words right off the page to find out what would happen to these lost children on this foreign island. Ralph, the protagonist, and Jack, the antagonist, were perfectly parallel at one point of the book, slowly but surely they began going their opposite ways. One focused on survival, the other on adaption. The events in this fictional book were so descriptive and colorful in an almost gory kind of way. This is a must read book!

His writing is like poetry! His ideas and views in how to describe landscape and human personality is unparalleled. All
kinds of readers will like this book.

William Golding’s novel, The Lord of the Flies, tells a captivating story about the loss of innocence, the conflict between the two innate human instincts of civilization and savagery, and the nature of evil. Readers are taken on a journey following the lives of a group of schoolboys who are stranded on a deserted tropical island after being the only survivors of a fatal plane crash. Being the only inhabitants of the island, the boys are free from all rules and standards which society formerly imposed upon them. Without any supervision the boys are left to govern themselves. Readers become captivated to see whether the boys’ impulses lead them towards civilization or savagery.
At first, the boys follow their human instincts and work together toward civilization, but simultaneously they struggle with the conflicting human instinct to descend into savagery, violence, and chaos. Inevitably, two tribes form with two different leaders and goals to illustrate the difference between civilization and savagery. Ralph’s group wants to build shelters and collect food, whereas Jack’s group would rather have fun and put all of their efforts into hunting. Jack’s tribe ultimately becomes the larger of the two as the boys’ instinct of savagery takes over the instinct of civilization. As time passes, conflicts arise and the tension between the two tribes grows tremendously. The tension causes violent outbreaks and chaos, which ultimately leads to the boys’ complete decline into the natural human instinct of savagery. By the time the boys are rescued, they have lost all innocence and learn that life will never be the same again because the nature of evil will still be a part of them even in the “civilized world.”
Lord of The Flies is a fascinating read that forces readers to not only examine the book, but also to look closely at themselves and their civilizations. I enjoyed reading Golding’s novel because it gave me an insight into human nature and the failings of society through a well thought out story with dynamic characters. Readers find themselves so involved in the novel that they cannot help themselves from imagining what they would do if they were put in the same situation. Lord of the Flies is a remarkable and powerful novel and should be on everyone’s bookshelf.ailings of society through a well thought out story with dynamic characters. Readers find themselves so involved in the novel that they cannot help themselves from imagining what they would do if they were put in the same situation. Lord of the Flies is a remarkable and powerful novel and should be on everyone’s bookshelf.
The Type is sooooo small.  I have to order a different one for my daughter for school.  Just be aware

column13: The grime you can never wash off
column14:
The generally accepted opinion for this book is that it is dark. I am fine with this. I have read dark books before, from Gaiman to the later-written books of the Harry Potter series; To Poe to Orson Scott Card to King, and several other tomes that fill my eyes with tears and my head with thoughts. I enjoy reading these works, for though they are dark and make me despair of humanity, and life and the pain that comes with it, it feels like a mud-bath for the soul; Though messy during the task, afterwards, you feel cleaner and think deeper for it. There is despair, yes, but it makes the triumph (Or grisly ending, in Poe's case) all the sweeter.
Golding did not write a book like any of these.
Instead, he writes an anvilicious (Look it up on TV Tropes) moralistic slog of why we are all horrible people. His book is like a tar-pit for the soul; It weighs you down, and if you manage to escape, it leaves a grime and a sheen that takes forever to rinse away. From his placid descriptions of the Eden-like island (All but to set it up to be burned to the ground later on, of course) to his outright psychotic characters, this book has brought me no joy, or perspective to humanity. (Other than further justifying my hypothesis that people who write terrible books inevitably get lauded by the academia for it)
The characters are stereotypical and infuriating in their actions, the plot-line contrived and based on coincidences, and the tone is cynical and condescending to the average reader. Don't read this book.
In fact, if I had a time machine, I would first go and tame a Tyrannosaurus Rex. The, while riding my T-Rex, I would go and punch Mr. Golding in the face.
He deserves it.
The book had lots of underlining and highlighting.  A bit distracting for the student who was reading it for a book report.
The last chapter of LORD OF THE FLIES is one of the most memorable in all of world literature. That chapter sealed William Golding's fate- the Nobel Prize.

column13: Kill the pig!  Spill his blood! and other things boys say.
column14:
Overall: it's a classic for a reason. A commentary on the mind and heart of man and the struggle between what we can do and what we should do set on an island paradise played out with a rag-tag bunch of boys.

What can be said about this classic tale of boys and their hearts. It is a tale as old as time and told in such a way as to last the ages. The struggles between three boys trapped on an island reflects the wars going on in ourselves, but also within society. The intellectuals, the hunters and the leaders all push for dominance and fight for their ways and only one can seemingly win.

Every young man should read this book so he can see how the wars inside his head and heart would play out on a desert island. It helps develop the sense of how one should not always follow the desires of the heart or be lead entirely by their head. Neither way is the answer, but rather a balance each and every man must develop on his own must be forged.

I would recommend this book to: young men, men, classic enthusiasts, readers and English literature lovers.

The copy I received was supposed to be in good to excellent condition. The pages were worn and yellow and the cover was tattered. It's absolutely the worst purchase I've ever made online. You should be ashamed of yourself to rate your books so dishonestly.

Len Bailey

column13: good book-bought it for my son for Christmas
column14: This is of course, a great book-twisted-but really good!  Bought this for my 14 year old son for Christmas.  He is an avid reader and thought he would appreciate this one. Satisfied with purchase-thanks!

I know what you’re thinking: this is just another high school novel forced upon adolescents everywhere. That was the first thought that ran across my mind when I saw this title. I actually had no idea what to expect. Lord of the Flies. The title doesn’t give away much, and the book’s so old the back summary only contained praise. So I plunged straight into a surprise when I began, and I would be lying if I said I loved it right away.

Let me inform you what the story is. Maybe this will prevent any more literary ignorance. The Lord of the Flies illustrates a story about a group of boys who get stranded on an island. The island is completely uninhabited, and the boys must learn how to fend for themselves. As time goes by and no rescuers make an appearance, the boys become more and more antsy. Arguments begin and sides are taken. With no adults to calm them, the boys’ antics at playing savage take a turn for the worst.

First, I need to make a disclaimer. I have no concept of allegories or symbolism or motifs hidden in stories. It’s ironic, because since I read so much, I should be a little better at this. Sadly, no matter how much practice I’ve had, I still haven’t the faintest idea of the underlying meanings in books.

That being said, this one was blatantly obvious. One scene basically summed it all up pretty nicely. The novel shows the loss of innocence, which is especially noticeable towards the end. It also portrays organization vs. chaos. The two sides the children split into represent the difference between order and savagery. One group is concerned with keeping up a smoke signal for ships, and the other has come to terms with their new home and busies themselves with play and hunting. It also demonstrates order is much more difficult to obtain and can be lost faster than chaos. Laying under the stars and eating meat turns out to be much more enjoyable than worrying about shelters and keeping up smoke signals for the boys.

I have to say I wasn’t in love with the beginning. It started out slow and confusing. Golding never explained how the children got stuck there, and the multitude of characters without names made it difficult to keep up with events. I even had to Sparknote a chapter towards the middle because I had no idea what was happening. Golding writes in a 3rd person perspective and doesn’t really let the reader connect with any of the characters through anything but actions.

The rest of the book, I adored. Once I got past the question how they got stranded (which was never answered), I could enjoy the book much more. Also, after the confusing chapter, the book picked up speed. The boys’ personalities shown through, and the reader began to feel the hopelessness that was edging into the backs of their minds.

**SPOILER ALERT** (I know, it is old. But you never know who hasn’t read it! I got The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde as well as The Great Gatsby spoiled by the same person.)

Can we just talk about the deaths in the book? Simon’s death after the scene which explained the deeper meaning in the book killed me. I was horrified the children would literally tear him apart with their bare hands. After his death, the situation became real to me. The boys began to break off into groups and I started to worry about the other characters I liked such as Piggy or Ralph.

I was absolutely right to worry. Piggy and Ralph split off from the others, and in a despute, Someone pushed a boulder onto Piggy! From the very beginning I connected with him. He represented the intelligent and rational mind of the kids, and he was so sweet and soft. I could tell from the very first page his death was coming, though.

The ending made me just plain sad. I felt so empty after I finished the book. Once the solider rescued Ralph from the other kids hunting him down like a wild pig, everything just stopped. The children, ranging from 5-12, seemed so ridiculous after contact with the outside world. They turned into savages and killed and hunted each other for no real reason.

I could just imagine all of them slowly appearing on the outskirts of the trees. Their faces smeared with blood and dirt, and their clothes tattered and filthy. They would look around and realize they can go home, and they’re safe. Then they’ll begin to realize what senile events they’ve gone through and instigated. Those thought will continue to haunt them for the rest of their lives. They have death on their hands. Images of Piggy being crushed and Simon’s small lifeless figure will never leave their minds. All innocence is gone forever.

Another symbol was the officer who retrieved the boys. He saved them from a manhunt, but now he’s going to embark on a manhunt just like theirs during the war. The beast inside them all never goes away. The Lord of the Flies is not a live being; it’s a monster which is present inside us all. The children turning to savages represents this idea. Nobody can save you from the monster. It continues whether you reside on a deserted island with children or whether you’re a grown man heading to war.

I love books that make me think; this one surely did. Despite the slow start, I grew to love it all the same. The more I think about it, the more I realize how wonderful this book is. Horrifyingly beautiful.

[...]e world. They turned into savages and killed and hunted each other for no real reason. I could just imagine all of them slowly appearing on the outskirts of the trees. Their faces smeared with blood and dirt, and their clothes tattered and filthy. They would look around and realize they can go home, and they’re safe. column13: Lord of the Flies Should Not Be Banned From Classroom Use
column14:
Lord of the Flies by William Golding is considered by many as one of the greatest literary works of all time. Even now it is being read in countless schools across the nation. A timeless classic, Lord of the Flies explores the depths of civilization, digging down to the core values of humanity. It follows the story of a group of children and their descent into savagery as they battle with the forces of good and evil.

Lord of the Flies has caused quite some controversy over the years. Some criticize it for being dark and including "gruesome imagery" at points. While that may hold true to some extent, the literary value of this novel far surpasses any negatives, such as violence, it may contain. As Common Sense Media said, "Parents need to know that Lord of the Flies has been described as dark, brutal, pessimistic, and tragic. Yet it deals with a fundamental issue of humanity... This and other issues in this novel would be invaluable for parent-child discussion, on both theological and humanist levels." According to Salve Regina University, a study was done in 1964 that showed more than 95% of public schools either had or were using this book. Lord of the Flies is a novel that draws out timeless themes through an outstanding display of breathtaking details, colorful vocabulary, and meaningful symbols.

column13: Lord of the Flies is an excellent book! (It should not be banned from schools.)
column14:
(Preface: This review is part of an extra-credit school assignment about whether classic books, such as LoTF, should be banned or not and why, so if the following seems a little different from an average Amazon product review, that's why.) :)

Lord of the Flies: Why It Should Not Be Banned

Reading William Golding’s famous novel Lord of the Flies recently was a fabulous experience. Its chronicles of friendship, betrayal, and the battle between civilization/”goodness” and man’s inner evil were both thrilling and intriguing. I read the book for a school assignment, and I must say that I was sorry that I had not read it earlier. It’s fascinating, and a great read for anyone above the age of 10 (there are a few gruesome scenes and images that may scare younger readers). Still, the violence is far from too graphic for middle-school students – for them the pros of reading the book outweigh the cons. Lord of the Flies is an extremely well-written tale with intriguing plots and ideas. Young teenagers should read the book because it teaches about human nature, and because censoring literature that teaches morals in an intense way is not censoring’s purpose.
William Golding’s novel Lord of the Flies is one of the best books on human nature ever written. In the story, British schoolboys crash on an island in the middle of the ocean. They try to create a sort of makeshift society, but due to the lack of parental supervision, it breaks down and results in anarchy – several of the boys die due to the chaos that ensues. By reading the story, children will learn about how the human psyche works – and how dependent we are on society. Lord of the Flies is an incredible book that contains many important things – some of these being civilization vs. savagery, individualism vs. community, the nature of evil, man vs. nature, dehumanization of relationship, the loss of innocence, and the negative outcomes of war. (What an incredible list – would anyone deprive a middle-schooler of knowledge on these profound topics simply because of one scene that is a little graphic?) Lord of the Flies is a novel of profound messages, themes, and morals, and censoring is not worth missing out on learning from the book.
A second reason why Lord of the Flies should not be banned is that doing so would defy the purpose of censoring books. When a board or organization bans a book, they are doing so logically because the book that they are banning has little or no literary value. Of course, Golding’s novel is far from that – as mentioned, it’s a work of literary genius with countless themes and lessons. Why ban a book and deprive students of such learning because of one scene? Teachers can allow students to skip the graphic parts, as many have done in my school. Besides, even if students choose to read even the scarier scenes, they are reading about human nature – they’re not watching a horror movie with pointless, excessive violence that has no meaning or point for its existence. Lord of the Flies may have gruesome parts, but those parts are educational and only help shine Golding’s messages brighter.
In conclusion, The Lord of the Flies should be taught in school, because of its incredible literary and moral value, and because censoring it would defeat the purpose of censoring books in the first place.middle-schooler of knowledge on these profound topics simply because of one scene that is a little graphic?) Lord of the Flies is a novel of profound messages, themes, and morals, and censoring is not worth missing out on learning from the book.
A second reason why Lord of the Flies should not be banned is that doing so would defy the purpose of censoring books. When a board or organization bans a book, they are doing so logically because the book that they are banning has little or no literary value. Of course, Golding’s novel is far from that – as mentioned, it’s a work of literary genius with countless themes and lessons. Why ban a book and deprive students of such learning because of one scene? Teachers can allow students to skip the graphic parts, as many have done in my school. Besides, even if students choose to read even the scarier scenes, they are reading about human nature – they’re not watching a horror movie with pointless, excessive violence that has no meaning or point for its existence. Lord of the Flies may have gruesome parts, but those parts are educational and only help shine Golding’s messages brighter.
In conclusion, The Lord of the Flies should be taught in school, because of its incredible literary and moral value, and because censoring it would defeat the purpose of censoring books in the first place.

I recently read Lord of the Flies, it was a great book. It truly show how mankind in its roots will revert to evil, and it is not easy to control that evil. Even what dwells within will not be easily controlled, and how it shows it in such description that creates a perfect atmosphere. Golding’s use of figurative language makes the story feel as if you were really there. He also describes it through a child’s perspective which creates it in such a different atmosphere compared to you or I would see it as. From what I’ve heard about it being inappropriate, I completely disagree with it all. Any gory or gruesome scenes only make the story more in depth, which creates a more beautiful story. The lose only pulls you more into the story, although you shouldn’t read it until your about nine or ten, but it just depends on your level of maturity. I wouldn’t buy it for your five year old, but maybe you’re eight year old if he/she is mature enough for the book. Lord of the Flies is a beautiful story, I would suggest everyone to read it, even twice to truly grasp everything. 10/10
